importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas-led attack that triggered the Israeli military campaign in Gaza, marking the start of the ongoing conflict.
The date when the ceasefire with Hamas came into effect, allowing a temporary halt to hostilities and enabling some humanitarian aid to enter Gaza.
The date of the news article's publication, signaling the current state of the Gaza health crisis and humanitarian response.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period spanning the 2023 Hamas attack and the subsequent conflict, during which Gaza has faced sustained Israeli military operations, leading to a long-term health and humanitarian crisis.

keyTakeAways: The Gaza health crisis is described as a 'catastrophe' that will last for generations due to famine, destroyed healthcare infrastructure, and widespread mental health issues.
Aid deliveries into Gaza are insufficient, with only 200–300 aid lorries per day instead of the required 600, and supplies intended for health reconstruction are being confiscated.

The World Health Organization (WHO) director-general, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, warns that the situation is catastrophic and beyond words, calling for unrestricted, unconditioned humanitarian access.
The ceasefire brokered by the US is fragile, with violations and renewed violence, and humanitarian access remains restricted despite international pressure.
Israel has imposed conditions on aid delivery, including restrictions on the return of hostages' remains, which the WHO criticizes as a violation of humanitarian principles.
The UN estimates that $70 billion is needed to rebuild Gaza, with about 10% dedicated to restoring the healthcare system.
Medical evacuation flights have been suspended for two weeks due to religious holidays in Israel, resulting in 700 deaths from prolonged waiting.
The destruction of water and sanitation infrastructure has led to disease outbreaks, compounding the health emergency.

namedEntities.name: Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director-General of the World Health Organization (WHO)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the primary source of the warning about the long-term health crisis in Gaza and is directly involved in urging humanitarian access and aid scaling.

namedEntities.name: World Health Organization (WHO)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WHO is central to assessing and reporting on the health crisis in Gaza and is calling for increased aid and access to medical supplies.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Nation conducting military operations in Gaza
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel controls access to Gaza and has restricted aid deliveries, including confiscating medical supplies and imposing conditions on aid flow, which is a key point of contention.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is involved in the conflict, has committed to returning hostages' remains, and is in ceasefire negotiations with Israel, making it a key player in the humanitarian and political dynamics.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US is credited with facilitating the ceasefire and has a responsibility under the article to ensure its implementation and protection of humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: OCHA reports on the progress of aid delivery and confirms that the starvation crisis is being mitigated, though not fully resolved.

namedEntities.name: World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP reports that over 6,700 tonnes of food have entered Gaza since the ceasefire, but this falls far short of the required daily target.

namedEntities.name: Kerem Shalom
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two main crossings through which aid enters Gaza, currently operational but insufficient to meet demand.

namedEntities.name: Kissufim
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The second primary aid crossing, also currently operational but insufficient to meet needs and facing calls to be fully reopened.

namedEntities.name: Gaza Strip
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The geographic and humanitarian focal point of the crisis, where healthcare systems have collapsed and millions face famine and disease.

namedEntities.name: 7 October 2023
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Date of Hamas attack on Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The event that initiated the military campaign in Gaza and is the root cause of the ongoing humanitarian crisis.

namedEntities.name: 28 hostages' remains
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Number of remains of hostages in Gaza
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key point of negotiation between Israel and Hamas, with only 15 of 28 remains transferred, leading to criticism over humanitarian restrictions.

namedEntities.name: 2,000 tonnes of food per day
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The minimum daily food delivery target set by the UN, which is not being met, highlighting the scale of the humanitarian shortfall.

namedEntities.name: 6,700 tonnes of food
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: An aggregate figure showing the current level of food delivery, still significantly below required levels.

namedEntities.name: 700 people dead due to medical evacuation wait
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Death toll from delayed medical flights
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A tragic consequence of the suspension of evacuation flights, emphasizing the urgent need for increased medical transport.

namedEntities.name: $70 billion reconstruction cost
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The total cost to restore Gaza's infrastructure, with 10% allocated to healthcare, underscoring the scale of the recovery challenge.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Health Organization's director-general, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, has warned that the health crisis in Gaza is a 'catastrophe' that will last for generations, driven by famine, destroyed healthcare systems, disease outbreaks, and severe mental health issues. Despite a ceasefire brokered by the US on 10 October 2025, aid deliveries remain critically insufficient—only 200–300 lorries per day instead of the required 600—with supplies being confiscated and access to crossings restricted. Dr. Tedros criticizes Israel for weaponizing aid, imposing conditions on the return of hostages' remains, and blocking humanitarian access, calling for full, unimpeded access to ensure recovery. The UN estimates $70 billion is needed for reconstruction, with 10% dedicated to healthcare. Medical evacuation flights have been suspended for two weeks, resulting in 700 deaths from prolonged waiting. The article emphasizes that the ceasefire is fragile, humanitarian access remains inadequate, and long-term recovery depends on political will and international cooperation.
title: Gaza health crisis will last for 'generations', WHO chief warns
